semantic_title: Sequencing ICD-10-CM Codes for Outpatient Encounters
section_path: Section IV > G. ICD-10-CM code for the diagnosis, condition, problem, or other reason for encounter/visit

content.full_text: List first the ICD-10-CM code for the diagnosis, condition, problem, or other reason for encounter/visit shown in the medical record to be chiefly responsible for the services provided. List additional codes that describe any coexisting conditions. In some cases, the first-listed diagnosis may be a symptom when a diagnosis has not been established (confirmed) by the provider. (Evidence: pg no: 113, L67-L69)
content.summary: Establishes sequencing rules for outpatient coding, prioritizing the chief reason for encounter with additional codes for coexisting conditions (Evidence: pg no: 113, L67-L69)
key_concepts: First-listed code is chiefly responsible for services provided (Evidence: pg no: 113, L67-L68)
List additional codes for coexisting conditions (Evidence: pg no: 113, L68)
First-listed may be symptom when diagnosis not established (Evidence: pg no: 113, L68-L69)

detailed_rules.rule_text: List first the code chiefly responsible for services provided (Evidence: pg no: 113, L67-L68)
detailed_rules.explanation: The primary code should represent the main reason the patient sought care and received services (Evidence: pg no: 113, L67-L68)

detailed_rules.rule_text: List additional codes for coexisting conditions (Evidence: pg no: 113, L68)
detailed_rules.explanation: Secondary codes should capture other conditions that coexist and may affect care (Evidence: pg no: 113, L68)

detailed_rules.rule_text: First-listed diagnosis may be symptom when diagnosis not established (Evidence: pg no: 113, L68-L69)
detailed_rules.explanation: When no definitive diagnosis is confirmed, a symptom code can serve as the first-listed diagnosis (Evidence: pg no: 113, L68-L69)

workflow_steps: Step 1: Identify the chief reason for the encounter
Step 2: Determine what was chiefly responsible for services provided
Step 3: Assign this as the first-listed diagnosis
Step 5: List coexisting conditions as additional codes
Step 6: Verify sequencing reflects service provision

references_to.title: Codes that describe symptoms and signs
references_to.explanation: Symptom codes may be used as first-listed diagnosis

coding_scenarios.scenario: Patient with diabetes presents for routine diabetic management and incidental hypertension
coding_scenarios.documentation_example: Patient here for routine diabetes follow-up. Blood sugar well controlled. Also noted to have hypertension, stable on current medications.
step_by_step: Step 1: Identify chief reason - diabetes follow-up
Step 2: Determine diabetes is chiefly responsible for services
Step 3: List diabetes as first-listed diagnosis
Step 4: Identify hypertension as coexisting condition
Step 5: List hypertension as additional code

correct_coding.sequencing: Chief reason first, coexisting conditions additional
correct_coding.rationale: First-listed code should be chiefly responsible for services provided (Evidence: pg no: 113, L67-L68)

incorrect_coding.rationale: Hypertension was not the chief reason for the encounter
incorrect_coding.common_mistake: Not identifying what was chiefly responsible for services

coding_scenarios.scenario: Patient presents with chest pain, no definitive diagnosis established
coding_scenarios.documentation_example: Patient presents with chest pain. Examination and initial workup inconclusive. Plan for further cardiac evaluation.
step_by_step: Step 1: Identify chief reason - chest pain
Step 2: Confirm no definitive diagnosis established
Step 3: Use chest pain symptom as first-listed diagnosis
Step 5: Complete coding with symptom code

correct_coding.sequencing: Symptom as first-listed when diagnosis not established
correct_coding.rationale: First-listed diagnosis may be symptom when diagnosis not established (Evidence: pg no: 113, L68-L69)

incorrect_coding.rationale: Should not assign definitive diagnosis when not established by provider
incorrect_coding.common_mistake: Assigning diagnosis codes when only symptoms documented

warnings: Do not assign diagnosis codes when provider has not established diagnosis
best_practices: Identify what was chiefly responsible for services provided (Evidence: pg no: 113, L67-L68)
Include all relevant coexisting conditions (Evidence: pg no: 113, L68)
Use symptom codes when appropriate as first-listed (Evidence: pg no: 113, L68-L69)
common_mistakes: Not identifying the chief reason for services
tips: The first-listed diagnosis should justify the services provided
implementation_notes: Requires clear understanding of encounter purpose
May require provider clarification on service focus
clinical_context: Outpatient encounters may address multiple conditions
Sequencing should reflect clinical priorities and service provision
